\begin{soln}
  Square all the identities and sum them up. This gives
  \[
    \sum_{i=1}^{2025} (x_{i}+x_{i+1})^2
    =4\sum_{i=1}^{2025} x_{\sigma(i)}^2
  \]
  which on expanding, simplifying, and re-factorizing
  gives
  \[
    \sum_{i=1}^{2025} (x_{i}-x_{i+1})^2=0
  .\]
  Thus all $x_{i}$'s are equal and we are done.
\end{soln}

\begin{soln}
  We use arrows to solve this problem. Draw a graph with the
  $x_i$ as the vertices and draw a directed edge
  from $x_i\to x_{\sigma(i)}$. It is well known that this
  graph can be decomposed into disjoint cycles (including
  $1$-cycles).

  \begin{claim*}
    Let $M=\max\left\{ x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_{2025} \right\}$. Then
    all the elements in a cycle containing $M$ must be equal
    to $M$.
  \end{claim*}
  \begin{subproof}
    FTSOC assume not. This means that there is another element
    $x_{i}$ in the same cycle as that of $M$ such that
    $x_{i}<M$.

    Firstly note that $2x_{\sigma(i)}=x_{i}+x_{i+1}
    <M+x_{i+1}\le 2M\implies x_{\sigma(i)}<M$. Similarly,
    $x_{\sigma(i)}<M\implies x_{\sigma(\sigma(i))}<M$.
    We can continue this pattern till we get back to the
    element with value $M$ which implies $M<M$
    giving our desired contradiction.
  \end{subproof}
  
  Now pick a cycle containing $M$. Therefore all the elements
  in this cycle are equal to $M$.

  Let the elements of this cycle be denoted as
  $\left\{ x_{i_1},x_{i_2},\ldots,x_{i_k} \right\}$. Here
  $\sigma(i_1)=i_2$, $\sigma(i_2)=i_3$ and so on up to
  $\sigma(i_k)=i_1$.

  Now, $x_{i_1-1}+x_{i_1}=2x_{i_2}\implies x_{i_1-1}=M$.
  Similarly, we can also derive that
  $x_{i_2-1}=x_{i_3-1}=\cdots=x_{i_k-1}=M$.

  Note that from the indices $\left\{ i_1,i_2,\ldots,i_k
  \right\}$, we just traversed to $\left\{ i_1-1,
  i_2-1,\ldots,i_k-1\right\}$. We can continue doing so
  till we cover all the indices modulo $2025$.

  This shows that all the elements $x_i=M$ and we are done.
\end{soln}
